Andy,

I think all these ideas are valid and deserve to be explored.  
Auto=
mation is a potentially significant future direction so 
heuristics for it =
are an interesting topic to pursue.  I think your 
suggestion about hidden =
layers is reasonable and could work in a lot 
of cases.  

Can you expand o=
n your idea about embedding?  How do you envision 
taking something already=
 evolved and embedding it into another 
network?  That sounds interesting (=
again because it can potentially 
exploit geometric relationships already u=
ncovered), but what are you 
envisioning would be involved?  Would the CPPN=
 also need to 
be "embedded" in some sense into yet another CPPN?  Or would=
 you just 
assume that one substrate a static structure that is now part of=
 some 
larger substrate that is operated on by another CPPN?

ken

> Ken,
> 
>    Two iss=
ues come to mind. The first is degree of required user 
> intervention in t=
he determination of substrate topology. The second 
> issue is embedability=
.
>

=
in

> evolutio=
nary process. The addition of hidden nodes to the substrate 
> topology fal=
ls outside the scalability of a Hypercube network

rease in resolution in the original 
dimensions 
> of the substrate input a=
nd output nodes.
> 
>    Taking your position regarding attempting to cast =
the problem in 
a 
> manner that facilitates the geometric relationships (I=
'm using the 
> term geometric to represent the larger n-dimensional design=

> it would appear that a reasonable approach would be to let the =

> problem dictate the substrate input and output nodes, and then 
simply 
=
> duplicate the substrate input and output nodes as substrate hidden 
> nod=
es, and let the thresholding of weights in the Hypercube network 
> separat=
e the wheat from the chaff. If there are input-to-input or 
> output-to-out=
put proximity relationships, they will emerge through 
> evolution of the H=
ypercube network.
> 
>    I'm just trying to somehow automate the process a=
nd let the user 
> focus on problem definition (i.e. substrate input and ou=
tput 
nodes). 
> If this approach is taken, then the genome would need to i=
nclude 
both 
> the substrate and hypercube topology definitions. 
> 
>    =
This leads into the second issue of embedability, or taking what 
> you hav=
e evolved and have the ability to embed it into a higher 
level 
> network.=
 Which is another one of the "multiple reasons" why I 
believe 
> the abili=
ty to maintain multiple unique inputs and outputs for a 
node 
> in a netwo=
rk, substrate or hypercube, is essential to the 
development 
> of more "br=
ain-like" networks.
> 
> Thanks,
>    Andy Carl

oups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:

outputs really are apples and oranges there is still valuable

ion that can be included with respect to how they are

ged.  It is not only the relationship of inputs 
to

elations of inputs to each other (and outputs 
to

potentially valuable.

d outputs are really 
> often 
> > going to truly be apples and oranges sin=
ce both normally will be 
at 
> > least about the same world, i.e. what I s=
ee in the world vs. what 
I 
> > do in the world; so there is an inherent c=
onceptual relationship 
> > between them in most contexts.  While it is pos=
sible to pose a 
> > problem in a way that removes some of that relationshi=
p (such as 
in 
> > your example), it should normally be possible to recast=

problem 
> > at least in part to restore it.  That is, there is more =
than one 
> way 
> > to pose a problem from a geometric standpoint.  In gen=
eral if the 
> > inputs and outputs are both about the same world, then som=
e 
method 
> > is probably available.
> > 
> > At the same time, even in ca=
ses where there is really no 
> > relationship whatsoever, there is still u=
tility in arranging the 
> > inputs and outputs separately in ways that cor=
respond to their 
> > respective geometric contexts.
> > 
> > ken
